docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Retirement Becomes a Rest Stop as Pensions and Benefits Shrink'' (front page, Feb. 9): How many millions of Americans make major life decisions based on the availability or affordability of health insurance? To work? To change jobs? To retire? To marry? To divorce?
docs.abstract: Betsy Britton letter says Americans are making decisions to work in their retirement years based on availability and affordability of health insurance; calls for universal health coverage (Feb 9 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Retirement Becomes a Rest Stop as Pensions and Benefits Shrink'' (front page, Feb. 9):    How many millions of Americans make major life decisions based on the availability or affordability of health insurance? To work? To...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE live-in customers at the Alcor Life Extension Foundation here reside in eight 10-foot-high steel tanks filled with liquid nitrogen. They are incapable of breathing, thinking, walking, riding a bike or scratching an itch. But don't refer to them as deceased. They may be frozen at minus 320 degrees Fahrenheit and identified by prisonlike numbers. But to Alcor, the 67 bodies -- in many cases, just severed heads -- are patients who may live again if science can just figure out how to reanimate them.

headline.main: Please Don't Call the Customers Dead

docs.abstract: Alcor Life Extension Foundation, small nonprofit company in Scottsdale, Ariz, has 67 bodies frozen in liquid nitrogen and awaiting medical breakthroughs that will enable them to be thawed and treated for whatever killed them; head and trunk of Ted Williams is most famous 'patient'; Alcor executives are convinced that cryonics will catch on someday and are stepping up marketing; nearly all future frozens buy life insurance policies to cover their fees and designate company as beneficiary; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Can the Alcor Life Extension Foundation, the home of Ted Williams's head, rescue patients from natural post-mortem deterioration?

docs.lead_paragraph: ANNMARIE HURLEY still remembers a conversation more than 13 years ago with her boss, Dr. Fred Danziger, as if it were yesterday. Dr. Danziger, a dentist in Long Beach, N.Y., asked Ms. Hurley, then a 26-year-old dental hygienist, if she had ever thought about disability insurance. She had not, but after listening to him and meeting with his insurance agent, she decided that the policy made sense. Three years later, when she developed pronator teres syndrome, a painful nerve problem, in one arm and carpal tunnel syndrome in both hands and was no longer able to do her job, the policy premium of $519 a year seemed like the best money she had ever spent. But in 1997, after a year and a half of collecting $2,250 a month in benefits, the insurer, First Unum, stopped paying, even though Ms. Hurley's contract provided for lifetime benefits. For eight years, Ms. Hurley, with the help of a lawyer, has been fighting the company, now called UnumProvident, to have benefits reinstated. So far, she hasn't had much luck.
docs.abstract: Scrutiny of business practices of UnumProvident, nation's largest provider of disability insurance, makes many people cautious about disability insurance in general; experts offer advice on what to look for in a policy and how to shop for one; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Anyone who does not have an investment portfolio large enough to cover monthly expenses should probably consider disability insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: DAY after agonizing day in the aftermath of the recent punishing snowstorm and single-digit temperatures -- there were delays, cancellations, equipment failures and overcrowded trains. In retrospect, it was perhaps the worst possible time for New Jersey Transit to ask for a fare increase. Still, some longtime passengers like Fran Duffy were philosophical.

headline.main: Fare Increase Is Only a Start At N.J. Transit

docs.abstract: Article on decision by cash-starved New Jersey Transit, facing $60 million loss in 2006, to seek second fare increase in three years despite not raising fares for more than decade before; increase, which must be approved by board before taking effect in April, would raise rail fares about 13 percent and cut discounts for traveling during off-peak hours to 12.5 percent from 25 percent; interstate bus fares would increase 13 percent while price of monthly passes for local buses would not rise; schedule of public hearings; graph; photos (L)
docs.snippet: DAY after agonizing day  in the aftermath of the recent punishing snowstorm and single-digit temperatures -- there were delays, cancellations, equipment failures and overcrowded trains. In retrospect, it was perhaps the worst possible time for New...

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR months, President Bush has pursued a two-step domestic strategy. Overhauling Social Security would come first, and only later would he try to revamp the federal tax code. But with resistance to the Social Security plan growing almost daily in Congress, lawmakers may force Mr. Bush to revise his strategy and pursue his tax agenda faster than he anticipated. Many House Republicans are more interested in dealing with the tax code than with Social Security, but the political difficulties inherent in tax reform make the risks high.

headline.main: Tax Reform Looks for a Passing Lane

docs.abstract: Republicans in Congress hoping to shift from income tax to some sort of consumption tax are pushing Pres Bush to combine that goal with his plan to partially privatize Social Security; potential advantage of marrying two agendas is to win maneuvering room to write legislation that would appeal to Democrats and have chance of becoming law, but risk could be huge political logjam; various ideas under consideration discussed (M)
docs.snippet: A growing number of Republicans, anxious about Social Security privatization plans, are now pushing Mr. Bush to combine that goal with tax overhaul.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI attributes New York's inability to balance its $105 billion budget largely to two problems: the exploding cost of providing health care services to the poor under its $44 billion Medicaid program and a court-ordered requirement to increase and equalize education spending by nearly $5 billion. But, as bad news often comes in threes, there's one more big-ticket item that few people are thinking about, and it may be as expensive: health insurance for the state's retired employees.
docs.abstract: Cynthia B Green Op-Ed article says huge cost of health insurance for retired state employees is major factor in New York's inability to balance budget (S)
docs.snippet: GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI attributes New York's inability to balance its $105 billion budget largely to two problems: the exploding cost of providing health care services to the poor under its $44 billion Medicaid program and a court-ordered requirement...
docs.section_name: Health; New York and Region; Opinion

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S no secret that surging health costs have become a C.E.O.-level issue. When a company like General Motors looks more each year like a giant health plan that operates a nice little nonprofit car business on the side, who wouldn't sound the alarm? But to many business leaders, their union counterparts' view of soaring health costs remains a mystery. Given union readiness to strike in the face of even modest efforts to slim generous health plans, these costs almost certainly doom unionized workers to few if any real wage increases for years to come. Do union leaders get this trade-off? Are they hamstrung by political dynamics that make it hard to approve even sensible health plan changes that can be cast as ''givebacks''? And what is their answer?

headline.main: Is Labor Out in Front On Health Care?

docs.abstract: Matt Miller column on reluctance of labor unions to negotiate 'givebacks' in their medical benefits, even if it means forgoing wage increases; Morton Bahr of Communications Workers of America and Andrew Stern of Service Employees International Union share their views (M)
docs.snippet: Union leaders may be thinking about the health system in ways more sophisticated and businesslike than many chief executives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Eastchester FOUR years ago, Eastchester became the first town in New York to grant health benefits for the domestic partners of gay employees. Recently, in a remarkable display of regression, the Town Board voted 3 to 2 to end them. This is a shame for several reasons. The sad truth is that the decision was about morality, not money. My successor, Supervisor Anthony Colavita, gamely claimed the town was simply trying to save money by eliminating the benefits. Yet they were used by only one person for a cost of $6,000 out of a $3 million benefits budget. That's less than 19 cents per year for each of Eastchester's 32,000 residents.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Jim Cavanaugh, former town supervisor of Eastchester, NY, offers reasons why he opposes decision by Town Board to stop granting health benefits to domestic partners of gay employees (M)
docs.snippet: Ending partner benefits for gay couples in Eastchester was unfair.
docs.section_name: Health; New York and Region; Opinion

docs.lead_paragraph: HEY, big spender. Here's a tax break for you: Beginning with 2004 tax returns, people who itemize their deductions may choose to deduct state and local sales taxes instead of state and local income taxes. In adding that provision, Congress clearly gave a break to residents of the seven states that have no income tax: Alaska, Florida, Nevada, South Dakota, Texas, Washington and Wyoming. Residents of the other 43 states can already deduct state and local income taxes, but in some cases, even in high-tax states like New York and California, they may be ahead by deducting sales taxes.

headline.main: It's Not Too Late To Save

docs.abstract: Roundup of ways Americans can reduce their taxes for 2004; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Some tax breaks for spenders big and small.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE actor Laurence Fishburne has bought a two-bedroom penthouse in an Upper West Side co-op from Alberta Wright, the owner of Jezebel, a theater district restaurant that specializes in Southern cooking. Ms. Wright has many friends in Hollywood and Mr. Fishburne is a longtime friend of Ms. Wright's son, Michael Wright, who is also an actor. Ms. Wright, who sold the apartment to Mr. Fishburne without listing it with a real estate broker, declined to specify the price. The penthouse in the West 80's was last on the market in the early 1990's, when it had an asking price of $785,000. It has two bedrooms, two bathrooms, a fireplace and two large terraces. Jonathan J. Miller, president of the appraisal firm Miller Samuel, said that while it is difficult to assess the value of an apartment without seeing it, ''apartments of this size in this neighborhood, if they are renovated and have outdoor space, generally sell in the low $2 million range.''

headline.main: Matrix Star Leaves Midtown For the Upper West Side

docs.abstract: Actor Laurence Fishburne buys Upper West Side penthouse co-op from Alberta Wright, restaurant owner; recently sold his West 57th Street condo; record label executive Alan Meltzer agrees to pay $27 million for apartment at Lexington Ave and 58th Street; Corcoran Group moves to cut its ties to Palm Beach, Fla, broker Peter David Burt, charged with trying to set up sexual encounter with underage girls via Internet; Barry Leistner plans to build small condominium building on Charles Street, Greenwich Village; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The actor Laurence Fishburne has bought a two-bedroom penthouse in an Upper West Side co-op.
